Cationic manganese (MnP - [Mn(T4MPyP)]5+) and anionic iron (FeP - [Fe(TDFSPP)]3–) metalloporphyrins in conjunction with zinc oxide of different morphologies, were synthesized. After characterization by different instrumental techniques, the metalloporphyrins were immobilized on the obtained zinc oxide and the catalysts were evaluated regarding the oxidation of cyclohexane, using iodosylbenzene (PhIO) as model oxidant. In the absence of light, the activities of FeP/ZnO were higher than those obtained by neat ZnO and MnP/ZnO. Furthermore, under the reaction conditions of 1:100:1000 catalyst/oxidant/substrate, with acetonitrile as solvent, for 1 h at 25 °C without any radiation source, the reactions were selective for ketone. The same occurred for the neat FeP under homogeneous conditions. In contrast, when the reaction proportions were changed to 1:20:1000 catalyst/oxidant/substrate and when the catalyst amount was increased 10 times, the selectivity was for alcohol. Under irradiation with a dichroic halogen lamp (50 W), all the systems containing FeP showed higher selectivity for alcohol, while when MnP was used, increments like those with FeP were not observed, probably due to the structural differences between FeP and MnP. This FeP to MnP replacement led to spectral differences that might have been responsible for the inability of MnP to interact efficiently with the radiation emitted by the dichroic halogen lamp as well as promoting the higher amount of ketone produced in comparison with the FeP/ZnO system. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Metalloporphyrin Catalysis ZnO Oxidation Cyclohexane Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Zinc oxide (ZnO) in its diverse morphologies has been used as a catalyst of different reactions, taking advantage of the redox potential present in the electron-vacancy pair that can be generated in this material, which is considered a semiconductor under the right conditions [1–6]. In some cases, ZnO alone is used as catalyst, such as in the experiments carried under light irradiation reported by Dehghani et al. [2], where the authors described the photodegradation of organophosphorus compounds, especially pesticides, catalyzed by commercial ZnO, with a significant increment in photodegradation compared to controls in the absence of ZnO. Some studies have also investigated the use of porphyrins and metalloporphyrins (MP) adsorbed on ZnO, since it is known that these molecules can act by harvesting visible radiation and promoting injection of excited electrons to ZnO [7–9]. In general, the works using ZnO/MP have sought complete oxidation or mineralization (conversion to CO2 and H2O) of different substrates and organic compounds considered harmful. Rabbani et al. [10], for example, showed that different solids containing ZnO modified with metals or meso-tetrakis(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrin complexes led to 99 % degradation of the methylene blue (MB) dye in 3 h under radiation in the visible light range, when a 400 W mercury vapor lamp was used as radiation source. Li et al. [11] immobilized two metalloporphyrin aggregates, one cationic and the other anionic, on ZnO microrods. The resulting catalysts caused more than 90 % degradation of rhodamine B dye after one hour of irradiation by a 1000 W tungsten lamp emitting light in the visible range and using only molecular oxygen as oxidant. Similar results of degradation were obtained by Sun et al. [1], who degraded rhodamine B using a catalyst containing non-symmetric copper metalloporphyrin immobilized on ZnO. The system was irradiated by a 400 W tungsten lamp using a cutoff filter for wavelengths shorter than 420 nm. In general, the works using either MB or rhodamine B as substrates in degradation reactions only followed the reaction progress through the reduction of absorption of the band attributed to the chromophore through electronic spectroscopy. The mentioned investigations [1], among others, generally report the use of ZnO, either pure or modified by different species capable of acting as catalysts by themselves or as sensitizers of semiconductors (e.g., porphyrins and metalloporphyrin), with the goal of promoting the generation of reactive species that can lead to substrate mineralization. These studies are prevalent, but in the context of ZnO use in light-assisted catalytic reactions, there are few reports where oxidation of the substrates have generated specific molecules or products that aggregate commercial value to the substrate, thus making it a material with potential industrial importance. Sharma et al. [12] used ZnO dispersed in a polyaniline (PANI) matrix to generate a composite (ZnO/PANI) that was then employed as catalyst of oxidation reactions of several organic sulfides as substrates in order to obtain the respective sulfoxides, which are important intermediates in industrial organic reactions. High yields and selectivity for sulfoxides have been achieved even when using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant, in a system described by the authors as “clean, safe and simple.” Wu et al. [13] reported the use of ZnO-Au aiming to modulate the amount of oxygen vacancies present as structural defects in ZnO during synthesis, since these vacancies have potential to attract electron density from gold particles in the material, making it a more pronounced Lewis’s acid, promoting the reaction with the substrate. The prepared material was then used as catalyst in the oxidation reaction of glycerol, yielding dihydroxyacetone, whose production according to the authors was related to the catalytic sites near the oxygen vacancies. The oxidation of hydrocarbons in the petrochemical industry is important to obtain molecules and products with higher added value [14,15]. Cyclohexane is one of the precursors of adipic acid, an oxidation product used as raw material to the production of polymers such as nylon-6.6, which has many industrial applications [16]. Other valuable, intermediate products of cyclohexane oxidation are cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol, which can be used not only for the production of adipic acid, but also, more importantly, as building blocks of other molecules such as caprolactam [16,17]. MP in solution and immobilized in several different supports [18–21] have been studied for catalytic oxidation of cyclohexane, in general showing good selectivity and efficiency for the production of cyclohexanol [22–25]. Machado et al. [26] recently showed that different second-generation metalloporphyrins [27,28], when immobilized on ZnO (obtained from in situ thermal decomposition of Zn5(OH)8(NO3)2 .2 H2O), were efficient and selective catalysts of cyclohexane oxidation, leading to around 20% yield with an A/K ratio of 18:1 in a system without irradiation. In this system, the control reactions using only ZnO showed almost no yield, suggesting that ZnO is not able to act as catalyst in this reaction by itself, instead only acting just as matrix to support the iron porphyrin. However, the authors did not explore the possibility of irradiating the system, which could cause the semiconductor properties of the supports to promote a combined, complimentary, and/or synergistic effect between them and the ability of the MP to interact with light in the visible range. There are several procedures to synthesize ZnO with different morphologies. The most frequently described procedure is to add a basic solution (commonly NaOH) to different zinc salts [29–31]. Some methods use surfactants to direct the growth of particles with specific morphologies [8,32–35]. Small changes in these methods can lead to materials with very different morphologies, even when using the same zinc salts and alkaline precipitation agents. A variety of systems have been studied for the preparation of ZnO particles with different shapes and sizes, since the nature of the resulting particles is highly dependent on the synthesis factors, as described by Musić et al. [34]. ZnO can be considered a material whose crystalline structure is polar, because during particle growth, atomic planes rich in zinc ions are formed that can attract anions along with oxygen-rich planes that can attract cations [36–38]. Thus, depending on size and morphology of the particles, ZnO can interact with negatively and positively charged species. The versatility of the metalloporphyrin/ZnO systems regarding their properties will depend on both the MP nature and the properties of the ZnO itself. However, only a few studies have explored these properties. In the present work, we contribute to the studies of metalloporphyrins immobilized on ZnO to produce hybrid oxidation catalysts by using either a cationic Mn(III) or anionic Fe(III) porphyrin. The synthesis procedures that lead to ZnO particles in the shape of spheres (ZnONS) and rod/bat like shapes (ZnONB) have often been described in the literature regarding reaction of zinc salts with a basic solution [3,10,29]. Once obtained, the different ZnO solids were used to immobilize two different MPs, represented in Fig. 1. Finally, MP-ZnO solids were used as catalysts for cyclohexane oxidation reactions, both in the dark and under irradiation using a controlled light source. A great deal of efforts has been devoted to design materials as photocatalyst for the activation of inert C-H bonds toward oxygenated organics for fine chemistry, fuels, or green catalysis [20,39–50]. The main contributions of the current study encompass the use of different ZnO morphologies and how they influence not only the interaction with the MP but also the catalytic results of the studied reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 General information All chemicals used in this study were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich or Merck and were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Iodosylbenzene (PhIO) was synthesized by hydrolysis of iodobenzene diacetate [51]. The solid was carefully dried under reduced pressure and kept at 5 °C, and its purity (99.6%) was assessed periodically by iodometric titration [51,52]. 2.2 Instrumental The electronic absorption spectra (UVVIS) of the solutions were obtained with an HP 8452A Diode Array UVVIS spectrophotometer, operating in the 200–800 nm range. The UVVIS spectra of the solid samples were obtained using a Varian Cary 100 BIO spectrophotometer by placing the samples in a Teflon sample holder and measuring the absorbance in the 200–800 nm range. Fourier-transform infrared spectra (FTIR) were obtained with a Bomen Michelson MB100 spectrophotometer in the range of 400–4000 cm−1, using KBr pellets. KBr was ground to a fine powder together with a small amount of each solid (ca. 1 % w/w), and the spectra were collected with resolution of 2 cm−1 and accumulation of 32 scans. Powder X ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were obtained with a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer operating at 40 kV and 40 mA (Cu-Kα radiation, λ = 1.5418 Å) with a scan speed of 2°/minute with Bragg-Brentano geometry of θ-2θ. The samples were prepared from a dispersion of the solid in a small amount of deionized water and placed on a glass sample holder to form a thin film, then dried and analyzed, or were previously pulverized and compacted directly on the sample holder. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements were performed with a JEOL JEM-1200 microscope operating at 110 kV. The solid samples were dispersed in propanone and deposited on FCF300-CU grids (300 mesh) with formvar/carbon film. Scanning electron microscopy images and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) spectra were obtained with a Tescan VEGA3 LMU microscope, using voltage of 10 KV. The samples were deposited on aluminum stubs and the EDS spectra were collected with a silicon drift detector (SDD) with area of 80 mm2 in the range of 0–10 KeV. The samples were gold sputtered to obtain the SEM images. The textural analysis was performed with a Nova 1000 analyzer (Quantachrome). The samples (about 0.1 g) were degasified under vacuum for a period of 2 h at 150 °C and later analyzed at liquid nitrogen temperature. The adsorption/desorption isotherms for N2 were obtained in a relative pressure range from 0.05 to 0.99, and the specific surface area was calculated using the multi-point Brunauer-Emmet-Teller method (B.E.T.), with relative pressure range from 0.05 to 0.3. Products from oxidation reactions were quantified using an Agilent 6850 gas chromatographer (with flame ionization detector) equipped with a 30 m long DB-WAX capillary column with 0.25 mm internal diameter (J&W Scientific). The products were quantified using n-octanol as internal standard. 2.3 Synthesis of porphyrins and metalloporphyrins The free base porphyrin [H2(TDFPP)] ([5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,6-difluorophenyl)porphyrin]) was synthesized and purified following the Lindsey methodology [53]. The sulfonation of the free base porphyrin was carried out following an adaptation of the procedure described by Turk et al. [54,55], resulting in the tetra-anionic free base porphyrin Na4[H2(TDFSPP)], which was then metalated according to the method described by Adler et al. [56]. The purification was performed by a chromatographic column having Sephadex 25 G as stationary phase and water as eluent, yielding pure Na4[Fe3+(TDFSPP)Cl] (FeP) with a Soret band showing maximum absorbance at 390 nm and ε ≈ 1∙104 L∙mol−1∙cm−1 in methanol. The manganese complex [Mn3+(T4MPyP)Cl5] (MnP) was previously synthesized and purified as reported in Pinto et al. [57], and the UVVIS spectrum of the MnP showed a Soret band with maximum at 464 nm and ε ≈ 8.00∙104 L mol−1 cm−1 in methanol. These FeP and MnP compounds have been routinely prepared in our groups throughout the years. The isolated metalloporphyrins were chromatographically and spectroscopically identical to previous preparations [53–57] or commercially available samples. 2.4 Synthesis of ZnO particles ZnO was prepared following the method described by Cheng et al. [58], with a few modifications, aiming to obtain particles with nanobat morphology (called ZnONB). Ethanolic solutions of NaOH (66 mL, 0.5 mol/L) and zinc acetate (33 mL, 0.1 mol/L) were added to a Teflon flask, which was then placed inside a steel reactor and left in an oven at 150 °C for 24 h. Then the supernatant was removed, and the solid was washed with deionized water until neutral pH, and then with ethanol, and dried in an oven at 80 °C for 48 h (0.966 g, 72% yield). ZnO particles with flower-like morphology (called ZnONF) were synthesized according to Bernhardt et al. [8], with adjustments of the synthesis scale. Briefly, 50 mL of ZnSO4 (0.2 mol/L) was prepared and added to 100 mL of the surfactant solution 2-[2-(2-methoxyethoxy)ethoxy]acetic acid (TODA) (0.2 mol/L), resulting in 150 mL of a 1:2 Zn2+/TODA solution, to which 50 mL of a NaOH solution (≈ 4 mol/L) was added dropwise. The resulting mixture was stirred for 5 min and then centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 10 min. The solid was rinsed with 10 mL of water, centrifuged again and rinsed twice with 10 mL of ethanol (0.716 g, 88 % yield). The synthesis of ZnONS followed the procedure described by Kawano et al. [29] An ethanolic solution of LiOH (200 mL, 0.15 mol/L) was transferred to an addition funnel and added dropwise to an aqueous solution of Zn(CH3COO)2 (120 mL, 0.15 mol/L) under vigorous magnetic stirring at room temperature for approximately 30 min. The reaction medium was kept under stirring for two more minutes and the solid was separated by centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 5 min, rinsed with 20 mL of water, and centrifuged again. The supernatant was collected and rinsed with 10 mL of ethanol, followed by repetition of the centrifugation step and dried at 90 °C for 18 h (1.11 g, 76% yield). ZnOZHN was prepared according to [59] by heating 150 mg of Zn5(OH)8(NO3)2·2 H2O - ZHN in a muffle oven for 1 h at 500 °C (heating rate of 100 °C/hour). Commercially available zinc oxide (Sigma-Aldrich, >99.0 %), called ZnOC, was and used without any previous treatment. All solids were characterized by FTIR, XRD, SEM, TEM and UVVIS. 2.5 Immobilization of the metalloporphyrins (MnP and FeP) on ZnO The immobilization of the metalloporphyrins FeP and MnP on the different ZnO samples was carried out as described here for the solid ZnONS. To 5 mL of ethanolic solution of MP (MnP = 1.92∙10−4 mol/L or FeP = 1.74∙10−4 mol/L), 20 mL of a dispersion of the solid ZnONS (≈ 7,5 mg/mL) was added. The resulting dispersion was kept under magnetic stirring at room temperature for 5 h, after which the solid was centrifuged and the supernatant was collected, quantified and analyzed by UVVIS. This procedure was used to indirectly determine the amount of metalloporphyrin immobilized per gram of solid (mol/g loading) based on the known molar absorptivity (ε) of each MP using the Soret band as reference. The solids were then dried at 80 °C for 48 h and labeled MnP/ZnONS or FeP/ZnONS. The same procedure was adopted for immobilization of MPs in the other ZnO solids, resulting in the following materials: MnP/ZnOC; FeP/ZnOC; MnP/ZnONB; FeP/ZnONB; MnP/ZnONF; FeP/ZnONF; MnP/ZnOZHN; and FeP/ZnOZHN. All of them were characterized by FTIR, XRD, SEM, TEM and UVVIS. 2.6 Catalytic activity studies of cyclohexane oxidation To investigate the catalytic activity, iodosylbenzene (PhIO) was chosen as oxidant and the cyclic and saturated hydrocarbon cyclohexane was selected as model substrate. The molar ratio between catalyst/oxidant (PhIO)/substrate (cyclohexane) was initially set at 1:100:1000 respectively. During the studies, this ratio was modified to 1:20:1000 and the amount of catalyst used was changed to 10 mg, with proportional maintenance of the other reactants, but keeping the same 1.0 mL of solvent added to the reaction medium. According to the initial conditions, the solid catalyst (1 mg) and the oxidant (4.5∙10−6 mol) were added to a reaction vial (1.5 mL), followed by addition of the solvent acetonitrile (1.0 mL) and the substrate cyclohexane (4.1∙10−5 mol). The catalytic reactions were carried out under magnetic stirring at room temperature in a dark chamber for one hour [41,60]. Thereafter, the reaction was inhibited by the addition of a saturated solution of Na2SO3. The catalyst was separated by centrifugation for 10 min at 4000 rpm, washed with methanol and acetonitrile, and then both the supernatant and washing solution were mixed quantitatively and analyzed by gas chromatography to determine the amount of product formed, using n-octanol as internal standard. All the reactions and analyses were carried out at least in duplicate. The same procedure was also used for the reactions assisted by light. The reaction vial was exposed to the radiation of an Avant dichroic halogen lamp rated at 50 W and 12 V with a G5,3 connector with luminous intensity of 1750 cd and color temperature of 3000 K, or a traditional halogen lamp (H) rated at 250 W and 250 V, with an E-11 connector. The reaction system was cooled by a water jacket to keep it at 25 ± 1 °C. All the experimental apparatuses used in these reactions were fit in a homemade white reaction box (0.65 m height, 0.55 m width and 0.55 m depth). The control reactions were performed in the presence or absence of ZnO in the same way as described above, except that in some instances no catalyst was used or pure ZnO (with no MP) was added instead of MP/ZnO solids. The corresponding MPs in homogeneous medium were also investigated as catalysts using similar reagent molar ratio. The experimental procedure was similar to that described for the heterogeneous catalysis. Catalyst reuse tests were also carried out with the most promising solids. The catalysts recovered at the end of the first use were washed with methanol and acetonitrile, dried at 60 °C, and reused in further reactions, adopting the same procedure described before. 3 Results and discussion The five different zinc oxide solids used in this work (ZnOC, ZnONB, ZnONF, ZnONS ZnOZHN) were prepared (except ZnOC) and characterized using XRD ( Fig. 2) and all the diffraction patterns were consistent with ZnO in polymorphic wurtzite structure [58] (JCPDS 01–1136), indicating the purity of the samples. According to comparison of all the XRD patterns considering the full width at half maximum (FWHM), the smaller crystalline domains were attributed to ZnONB (Fig. 2b), since the diffraction peaks are broadened in comparison with the other samples. Another characteristic of ZnONB is the intensification of the diffraction peak indexed as (002), indicating the exposure of these planes in the particles, which can be related with their elongated morphology. The opposite behavior was observed in the sample ZnOC (Fig. 2a), where the exposed planes were (100). This difference can also be noticed when comparing other X-ray patterns described in the literature for elongated morphologies, such as bats, rods or needles. However, depending on how long they are or the aspect ratio of the solid, it was not always possible to notice that phenomenon. The synthesized ZnO materials were also analyzed by diffuse reflectance UVVIS (Fig. SI-1). We expected the different routes adopted here would lead to solids with structural characteristics such as particle size and morphology [29] that could affect the transitions related to their band gap [61,62]. However, all ZnO samples presented very similar spectra, containing only a band of intense absorption at wavelength shorter than 400 nm. Nevertheless, the position of this band allowed estimating the optical band gap of the solids. By extrapolating a tangent line drawn in the region in which the absorption starts, according to the Tauc plot, an average value of 3.18 ± 0.011 eV was obtained for the different ZnO samples. The bands observed were similar to what we expected for the bulk form of ZnO, more so than that of nanoparticles, since the quantic confinement effects generated by the nano scale likely influenced the observed band gap so that the smaller particles tended to present a blue shift in this band [6,62–64]. Since there were almost no differences in the registered spectra and a small standard deviation value was obtained for the band gap, it was not possible to differentiate the synthesized solids using this technique. This could be related to the fact that the particles were not monodisperse in size or even that they were not small enough for the quantic effects to be detectable. The solids were also analyzed by FTIR ( Fig. 3) and the samples could be divided in two series: (i) ZnOC (Fig. 3a), ZnONB (Fig. 3b) and ZnONF (Fig. 3c), with vibration bands at 547 and 507 cm−1; and (ii) ZnONS (Fig. 3d) and ZnOZHN (Fig. 3e). In the sample ZnONS (Fig. 3d), a less intense band in the region around 3500 cm−1 might have been related to the O-H vibrational modes of water molecules adsorbed on the material [65,66]. To analyze the morphologies in detail, all the ZnO samples were also characterized by TEM ( Fig. 4). Initially, it is noticeable that the ZnOC particles had no well-defined shapes (Fig. 4), which is expected for a commercial material. For the ZnONB, the images (Fig. 4b) show abundance needle-shaped particles. Even though no modifications were made in the synthetic procedure described in literature [58], the preparation of methanolic and ethanolic solutions of NaOH described as usual was not so trivial, especially with high concentrations of NaOH. This might have been the origin of the differences in the results obtained in this work and those reported in the reference. The TEM images of the solid ZnONF (Fig. 4c) showed morphologies resembling pseudo-flowers, which was expected according to the procedure used in its synthesis [8]. However, the solid obtained by Bernhardt et al. yielded particles that were better defined and smaller, resembling flowers since they grew spherically from a common point in the middle [28]. The SEM images (not shown) for the solid indicated particles of various sizes with platelet-like morphology agglomerated on the surface, which was more irregular than the surfaces of the other ZnO samples in this work. The TEM images of ZnONS (Fig. 4d) exhibited some almost cylindrical particles associated with larger structures without a homogeneous form suggesting the presence of layered particles. There was a large contrast between these two kinds of particles, suggesting that the cylindrical ones were more densely packed, since the electronic beam used in this technique cannot pass through them, making them appear darker in the images. Kawano et al. [8,29] described obtaining spheres with diameters smaller than 50 nm employing this same method. The TEM images of the solid ZnOZHN (Fig. 4e) revealed the presence of pseudo-spherical particles forming small aggregates. Since the precursor ZHN is a layered material with platelet-like particles [41], this change of shape can be evidence of conversion of ZHN to ZnO. In the SEM images (not shown) of the same solid, it was possible to notice structures resembling flakes or plaques forming fairly organized piles to form the solid grains. This kind of structure is the result of partial retention of the ZHN morphology (Fig. SI-2) after the thermal decomposition of ZHN to ZnOZHN. The specific surface area of the solids was measured through the adsorption and desorption of nitrogen, indicating wide variation of the solids’ surface area ( Table 1). The specific surface area values obtained for the ZnO solids were between 17 and 37 m²/g, except for ZnOZHN, which had a value 10-fold smaller than the largest one measured for the other solids. In other reports, similar surface area values can be found [67,68]. The highest surface area was observed for the solid ZnONS and the smallest (3.78 m²/g) was close to that of its precursor ZHN (7.12 m²/g). The shape of the adsorption and desorption isotherms obtained for all the solids, except ZnOC were similar to those of other nanostructured zinc oxides in the literature [68] (Fig. SI-3). The profile was classified, according to the IUPAC, as type III, which is usually present in macro or nonporous materials [60,61]. According to the same classification, the hysteresis present in the isotherm is an H3 type, usually associated with microporous materials [69]. 3.1 Characterization of the zinc oxide samples containing immobilized FeP or MnP After the immobilization reactions of FeP or MnP on the different ZnO solids, the respective supernatants were analyzed by UVVIS to indirectly determine the amount of the complex that was retained in the solids and calculate the loading of MP ( Table 2). In all cases (Table 2), anionic FeP had higher loading values than cationic MnP in the studied solids. This means that independently of the shape and size of the support, there was likely predominance of residual positive charges on the solid surface. On the other hand, despite the seemingly smaller ability to interact with positively charged complexes, these compounds also were immobilized in the materials, indicating the polar characteristic of the solids. The solids resulting from the immobilization of FeP and MnP on ZnONF had higher loading values compared to the other supports, suggesting that independently of the MP load, this solid had better interaction than the others, despite not having the highest surface area. This is not easily explained, but it might be related to the fact that this solid presented irregularities on its surface, which might have promoted better contact with the species in solution, leading to higher loading as well as exposing different crystallographic surfaces, as observed by XRD (Fig. 2). ZnONS and ZnONB had the highest surface area (Table 1), but they did not have the highest MP loading values (Table 2), which suggests that not all the surface area measured via B.E.T. was accessible to interact with the MP, possibly due hindrances associated with MP size and volume, or some limited residual charge, restricting the electrostatic interaction between ZnO and MP. These factors may have caused the divergence from the expected behavior of higher area leading to higher loadings. All the solids resulting from the immobilization of FeP and MnP on the synthesized ZnO solids were also analyzed by UVVIS ( Figs. 5 and 6, respectively) to analyze the adsorbed metalloporphyrin in detail. In all the spectra of the FeP-containing materials depicted in Fig. 6, the spectral profile of M3+P can be seen, with a Soret band at 409 nm. FeP in solution usually shows a Soret band with maximum at 390 nm. Thus, a bathochromic shift of the band occurred during the immobilization, suggesting that the macrocycle was distorted during the process [26,60,70]. This type of spectral shift has been reported before in the case of other MP immobilizations on different supports [26,60], usually ascribed to porphyrin ring distortions to maximize the interaction with the residual charges of the support. In the case of ZnO/MnP materials, which had smaller loadings (Table 2), all the spectra (Fig. 6) contained a band with maximum at 464 nm, which was expected for this Mn3+P in solution. Unlike the FeP cases (Fig. 5), the Soret band of the MnP systems had low intensity, probably due to the small amount of MnP in the solids, except for MnP/ZnONB and MnP/ZnOZHN. Additionally, bands were present at wavelengths shorter than that of the Soret band, especially for the solids MnP/ZnOc, MnP/ZnONF, and MnP/ZnONS (Fig. 6a, c and e respectively), which could be related also to the presence of some manganese(II) species, as observed by Westrup et al. [9], suggesting that the interaction of MnP with the structural defects of ZnO, such as oxygen vacancies or unsaturated bonds on the solid surface, could act as reducing agents of the manganese ions, causing conversion of a fraction of the immobilized manganese(III) porphyrin to the corresponding manganese(II) porphyrin. The XRD analyses of the FeP/ZnO and MnP/ZnO, exemplified by the ZnOC, were closely similar ( Fig. 7) to those previously presented in Fig. 2. This indicates that the immobilization of the complexes did not influence the structure. 3.2 Cyclohexane oxidation Initially, the cyclohexane oxidation reactions by iodosylbenzene in acetonitrile were carried out with a catalyst/oxidant/substrate molar ratio of 1:100:1000 in the dark, and with a reaction scale of 1.0 mg of catalyst (Condition A). Control reactions without MP catalysts generated low amounts of cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol without significant selectivity ( Fig. 8). The results of the reactions with the neat ZnO (ZnONF, ZnONS and ZnOZHN) as catalysts indicated that ketone was the main product (ketone/alcohol selectivity = 15 for ZnONS, 16 for ZnONF 18 for ZnOZHN), suggesting the classic radical mechanism described for alkane oxidation [17]. The proposal mechanism [17] ( Fig. 9) shows that in the presence of oxidant, the reaction proceeded through a radical path that may have led to both alcohol and ketone products, but with excess oxidant, higher amounts of ketone were likely obtained by alcohol re-oxidation. Additionally, A larger surface area of the ZnO used as catalyst was associated with a higher total yield (% alcohol +% ketone = 14.9 % for ZnONS, 8.5 % for ZnONF and 5.8 % for ZnOZHN). This was expected, since a larger surface can facilitate contact among substrate, oxidant and catalyst during the reaction, leading to higher yields. The high surface area of the ZnONS solid could be related to its spherically shaped particles, while the reduced surface area of the ZnOZHN may have been due the partial retention of the ZHN precursor. The results shown in Fig. 8 thus suggest that the morphologies and surface areas of the synthetized solids were relevant for their catalytic activity. The reaction catalyzed by FeP in homogeneous medium resulted in very low total yield (4.5 %), with slight predominance of ketone over alcohol (Fig. 8). Although MP is a robust molecule with respect to destruction through ring oxidation [27,28], the large excess of iodosylbenzene used in these reaction condition (100:1 oxidant/catalyst) could lead to destruction of the FeP, resulting in the low yields (Fig. 8). Comparison of the results in homogeneous medium (1.7 % alcohol and 2.8 % ketone) and the control reaction without catalyst (0.6 % alcohol and 1.0 % ketone) revealed a negligible increase in yields, suggesting the destruction of the FeP. The reactions catalyzed by the solids containing FeP (FeP/ZnONF, FeP/ZnONS and FeP/ZnOZHN) exhibited yields that were not significantly greater than those using the neat ZnO solids alone (16.8 % FeP/ZnONS > 12.2 % FeP/ZnONF > 2.8 % FeP/ZnOZHN). Additionally, immobilization of FeP on ZnOZHN to yield FeP/ZnOZHN reduced the catalytic efficiency of the solid. However, the reason for this inhibition was not clear and was not investigated further. When immobilized, FeP is expected to resist oxidative processes that could cause the destruction of the molecule [27,28]. However, the catalytic performance observed in Fig. 10 suggests that the high ratio of oxidant to FeP was the cause of destruction of the iron porphyrin, both in solution (homogeneous medium) and when immobilized on ZnO. Evidence of this destruction was indicated by the bleaching of the catalyst color at the end of the reactions under the previously mentioned conditions. The color of the solids changed light yellow to white. Reactions using a lower molar oxidant ratio of 1:20:1000 (Fig. 10 Condition B) were performed to investigate and try to reduce the destructive effects of the excess of oxidant in relation to the FeP catalysts under homogeneous conditions. The change of the molar ratio between catalyst and oxidant from 1:100–1:20 resulted in a total product yield (A+K) of 5.9 %, despite the fact the reaction presented higher selectivity for the alcohol product, as was expected for FeP. The control reactions without catalyst were not significantly affected, with yield smaller than 2% with slight selectivity for the ketone product. Still using the molar ratio of 1:20:1000 (catalyst/oxidant/substrate), we increased the amount of catalyst mass 10 times while keeping the same volume of solvent added (1 mL) (Condition C). Under these scaled-up conditions, a total product yield of 17.1 % was observed, with high selectivity for alcohol, closer to the results reported by Machado et al. [71]. Using these optimized reaction conditions (1:20:1000 catalyst/oxidant/substrate with 10 times more catalyst, Condition C), we also investigated the ZnO solids with immobilized FeP as catalyst and the control reactions employing only the neat ZnO as catalysts. The yield trend was essentially unchanged. Like in the non-optimized conditions (Fig. 10, Condition A), the solid ZnONS and ZnOZHN presented the highest and lowest yields respectively (total yields: ZnONS 3.8 % > ZnONB 2.9 % > ZnOC 2.5 % > ZnOZHN 2.3 %), suggesting that the surface area still played a major role in the reaction yield when the neat ZnO solids (without FeP), with different morphology, were used as catalysts (control reaction). When the solids containing FeP (FeP/ZnOC, FeP/ZnONB, FeP/ZnONS, and FeP/ZnOZHN) were investigated as catalysts ( Fig. 11), one can notice that: (a) all the FeP/ZnO solids were markedly more efficient catalysts than their corresponding neat ZnO controls, suggesting a catalytic role of the immobilized FeP; (b) all the FeP/ZnO solids led to high alcohol selectivity, also indicating FeP as a catalysis promoter under these conditions; (c) FeP/ZnONB was the most efficient (total product yield (alcohol+ketone) = 20.3 %) with high selectivity (%alcohol/%ketone = 7.5), suggesting that the immobilized FeP, under these conditions, was slightly more robust than the FeP in solution (homogeneous control; total product yield = 17.1%,%alcohol/%ketone = 9.7); and (d) the total yield (alcohol+ketone) of the reactions catalyzed by the FeP/ZnO solids (Fig. 11) under the optimized reaction condition (1:20:1000 catalyst/oxidant/substrate, mass of catalyst = 10 mg) did not follow the tendency observed before under non-optimized reaction condition (1:100:1000 catalyst/oxidant/substrate, mass of catalyst = 0.1 mg) in which the catalyst solid with ZnO solids with greater surface area (Table 1, solid ZnONS) resulted in higher yields (Fig. 8, solid FeP-ZnONS = total yield = 16.8 %). From the results presented in Fig. 11, the following trend of total yield% was observed: 20.3 % FeP/ZnONB > 15.7% FeP/ZnOZHN > 7.9 % FeP/ZnOC > 5.1 % FeP/ZnONS. This trend again suggests that under optimized condition (Condition C, Fig. 10), FeP played the major role as catalyst while the ZnO matrix and their different morphologies and surface areas did not significantly influence the activity of the FeP/ZnO solid catalysts. Reactions using irradiation were also carried using the optimized molar ratio condition. For these experiments, we tested two different radiation sources: a common halogen lamp (250 W) and a dichroic halogen lamp (50 W). The main difference between them, besides the wattage, is heat emission. The dichroic lamp generates less heat in its surroundings than the common lamp, making it easier to control the reaction temperature. The emission spectra of both lamps are similar (Fig. SI-4) since they are both halogen lamps, so that both consist of a tungsten filament enclosed in a quartz bulb containing an inert gas mixture containing a halogen gas, such as iodine [72]. The emission of these lamps is continuous along the whole visible region, to the beginning of the UV region, with a maximum of emission around 600 nm. Most of the radiation emitted by these lamps is able of interact with the MP used in this work. However, only a small part would be capable of interacting with the zinc oxide band gap in the UV range. In the irradiated experiments, the same reaction conditions as previously used (without irradiation) were maintained. To counteract the heat caused by the lamp, the system was cooled by circulating water in the outer walls of the reactor built for this reaction. The reactor was irradiated from the top so there was no barrier between the radiation source and the reaction solution. The distance between the center of the lamp filament and the surface of the solution inside the reactor was kept at 10 cm. When comparing the results of the cyclohexane oxidation reactions in the absence of radiation (Fig. 9) with the corresponding reactions under irradiation from the dichroic halogen lamp ( Fig. 12), a slight increase in the yield was observed for all the solids even in the homogeneous control reaction using only FeP as catalyst. This increase was not followed by any change of selectivity, indicating that the radiation might have been the cause. The increase in yields was more pronounced for the catalysts containing ZnO, suggesting that the interaction responsible for this increase might have happened preferentially with the support, since the reaction using only FeP as catalyst had the smallest increment. Reactions using irradiation were also carried out under the optimized molar ratio and mass of catalyst condition (Condition C, Fig. 10) ( Fig. 13). Initially it can be noticed that the reaction in absence of any catalyst (just with cyclohexane, iodosylbenzene and acetonitrile, control reaction), did not show any significant difference from the counterpart without irradiation (Fig. 12). The reaction catalyzed by FeP under homogeneous conditions, however, had a total yield of 46.9 % and %alcohol/%ketone selectivity = 19.4. The yield of the irradiated reactions was 2.9 times higher than the yield in the dark, suggesting that the radiation also had an influence on the catalytic activity of FeP, probably by accelerating the traditional mechanism, described for the oxidation of hydrocarbons by MP, causing a solvent cage collapse ( Fig. 14, species depicted in C), since the ketone yield increased 1.4 times while the alcohol yield increased 2.9 times. Various studies published in recent decades reporting the use of MP as catalysts in homogeneous media have demonstrated their efficiency for cyclohexane oxidation [20,71,75–79] using iodosylbenzene and other oxidants, with high selectivity for alcohol, sometimes yielding 10 times more alcohol than ketone. This selectivity can be explained by the mechanism presented in Fig. 14 [9,73,74,80,81]. This proposed mechanism consists initially of an oxygen atom transfer from the oxidant to the MP (A) generating a π-cation radical species with the metallic ions and the porphyrin ring being oxidized by one electron each. Then in (B), this species interacts with the substrate by abstracting one of its hydrogen atoms to cause homolytic cleavage of the hydrogen-substrate bond, generating a radical (R-C•) and a hydroxo-metalloporphyrin species. Both radical and high-valent metal-hydroxo species are held in a so-called solvent cage environment (C), which strongly influences the path followed by the reaction, and consequently the product obtained in highest amount [74,75,80,81]. The lesser the stability of the cage, the faster it collapses, leading preferentially to the alcohol product. On the other hand, a more stable cage allows rearrangements of the radical species and oxygen traces can lead to ketone. Usually, given the reactivity and proximity of the species within the solvent cage, an oxygen rebound mechanism takes place and the hydroxyl group from the hydroxo-metalloporphyrin is transferred to the substrate radical, yielding alcohol. Under optimized conditions, it is clear that FeP is able to interact with the radiation emitted by the lamp, leading to an increase in the total yield. In the reactions involving just the neat zinc oxide (ZnOC, ZnONS, and ZnOZHN), a small increase was also noticed in the reactions that were assisted by light, while in the dark, no significant selectivity was observed. In the reaction using FeP/ZnOC, FeP/ZnONS or FeP/ZnOZHN as catalyst, comparison of yields in the dark with those assisted by light ( Table 3) revealed that in general all the solids presented some increment in the total yield, suggesting that the solids with higher FeP loading also presented higher total yield, so that their performance cannot be directly related with the specific surface area of the ZnO solids involved. The higher yields under irradiation and under the optimized conditions were also substantial, considering that the higher amount of catalyst meant more solid particles dispersed in solution during the reaction, which could increase light scattering by the Tyndall effect. Nevertheless, the yields were still higher under light. Experiments to evaluate how robust the synthesized solids were for reuse were also carried out, since as heterogeneous catalysts, they could be recovered at the end of the reaction easily. The solid FeP/ZnOZHN was chosen for the reuse test. Thus, between one reaction cycle and the next, the solid was rinsed with solvent, as described in the experimental section, with the intent of removing possible adsorbed reaction products, and then dried at 80 °C overnight without any drastic procedures being carried out. There was some variation in the total yield, but after the fourth reuse, the trend was for the yield to stabilize. A few factors might have contributed to this effect, such as the possible leaching of some FeP during the reuse cycles, which could be also relocated by re-immobilization on the solid surface. This was monitored by UVVIS (Fig. SI-5), and the spectra showed bands indicating the presence of FeP in solution. However, the stabilization of the yield after the fourth cycle the yield suggest that the FeP weakly supported on ZnO had been completely eliminated, so no further leaching was observed. As previously described, the surface area also appears to affect the results, especially when there is no FeP involved. Thus, a second factor that might cause the fluctuation of the total yield during the reuse cycles was the change of morphology and surface area caused by grinding of the catalyst particles during magnetic stirring. This effect accumulated with each reaction cycle. To investigate this observation, the surface area of the solid FeP/ZnOZHN recovered after the fifth reuse cycle was measured again. The surface area increased from the initial 3.78 m²·g−1 to 5.56 m²·g−1 after the fifth reuse. However, that increase was probably not large enough to account for the observed fluctuations. The change in the surface area also indicates morphological changes. Comparison of the SEM micrographs of the solid after reuse (Fig. SI-6) with those before use (Fig. SI-2) revealed that the previous partially preserved morphology of its precursor no longer resembled the layered material in any aspect, probably meaning this change was due to the effect of mechanical abrasion and particle breakage, consequently increasing the surface area. Reactions aiming to compare two different MP samples, FeP and MnP, in solution and immobilized in ZnOZHN were also performed ( Fig. 15). A difference in the behavior of the solids containing MnP was observed with respect to the FeP samples, especially regarding the selectivity of the reactions. As discussed by Westrup et al. [9], despite the reaction mechanism of MnP and FeP being similar [82,83], MnP caused stronger stabilization of the active species in the solvent cage, favoring the radical escape route and leading to higher ketone production in the reactions using MnP or MnP/ZnOZHN in contrast to what is observed for FeP under the same reaction conditions. Considering the total yield of the reaction carried out in the dark, MnP presented slightly higher yield (19.2 %) than that of FeP (17.1 %). However, FeP was considerably more selective for alcohol (%alcohol/%ketone = 9.7) than MnP (%alcohol/%ketone = 1.4). On the other hand, in the irradiated reactions, whereas FeP tripled the total reaction yields compared to the reaction carried out in the dark, MnP did not show relevant changes. The same behavior was observed in the MnP/ZnOZHN solid. Overall, this suggests that the radiation from the lamp might not have been adequate to interact efficiently with MnP to produce an increase similar to that obtained using FeP. 4 Conclusion Different novel ZnO-porphyrin hybrid materials with expressed catalytic activity in oxidation reactions assisted (or not) by light was presented in this study. Through different synthetic routes, ZnO samples with different morphologies were prepared and used as support to immobilize FeP and MnP. The results indicated that independently of the morphology, the solids could interact with both metalloporphyrins with preference to the anionic FeP. The different loading values obtained also suggested that the surface area might play a role in the immobilization process, along with the orientation of the particles to expose specific crystallographic planes. Under optimized reaction conditions (catalyst/oxidant/substrate molar ratio of 1:20:1000 and increase of the catalyst amount used per reaction), minimal FeP destruction by excess oxidant higher alcohol selectivity and higher efficiency were achieved, with results comparable to non-immobilized MP-based catalysts in general. Since the activity of FeP was much higher than observed for the different neat ZnO solids, the effect of the morphology played a secondary role and the amount of FeP in each solid gained greater importance in the catalytic performance of the FeP/ZnO solids prepared. The reactions irradiated by the dichroic halogen lamp were as selective as their non-irradiated counterparts, but of increased total yield. Instead of acting as a ZnO sensitizing agent, as we initially hypothesized, the radiation likely increases the FeP activity through the traditional Fe-oxo mechanism. After reaction condition optimization, all the systems containing FeP showed high selectivity for alcohol, and despite the low power of the dichroic halogen lamp (50 W), the results obtained in the irradiated reactions were comparable to those reported by other researchers using much stronger irradiation sources [9,19]. On the other hand, when MnP was used instead of FeP, we could not observe an increment similar to that of FeP, probably due to structural differences between FeP and MnP. This FeP to MnP replacement led to spectral differences that might have been responsible for the inability of MnP to interact efficiently with the irradiation emitted by the dichroic halogen lamp, as well as to promote the increased amount of ketone produced in comparison with FeP. coredata.dc:description: Cationic manganese (MnP - [Mn(T4MPyP)]5+) and anionic iron (FeP - [Fe(TDFSPP)]3–) metalloporphyrins in conjunction with zinc oxide of different morphologies, were synthesized. After characterization by different instrumental techniques, the metalloporphyrins were immobilized on the obtained zinc oxide and the catalysts were evaluated regarding the oxidation of cyclohexane, using iodosylbenzene (PhIO) as model oxidant. In the absence of light, the activities of FeP/ZnO were higher than those obtained by neat ZnO and MnP/ZnO. Furthermore, under the reaction conditions of 1:100:1000 catalyst/oxidant/substrate, with acetonitrile as solvent, for 1 h at 25 °C without any radiation source, the reactions were selective for ketone. The same occurred for the neat FeP under homogeneous conditions. In contrast, when the reaction proportions were changed to 1:20:1000 catalyst/oxidant/substrate and when the catalyst amount was increased 10 times, the selectivity was for alcohol. Under irradiation with a dichroic halogen lamp (50 W), all the systems containing FeP showed higher selectivity for alcohol, while when MnP was used, increments like those with FeP were not observed, probably due to the structural differences between FeP and MnP. This FeP to MnP replacement led to spectral differences that might have been responsible for the inability of MnP to interact efficiently with the radiation emitted by the dichroic halogen lamp as well as promoting the higher amount of ketone produced in comparison with the FeP/ZnO system.
coredata.dc:title: Metalloporphyrin/ZnO solids as selective catalysts for oxidation reaction assisted by light
